comment.author: 16489083@N05
comment._content: "ACCIDENT," SAYS PAVLOVA.; But Novikoff's Wife Says Slap Was Intentional -- He Has Quit Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES. August 10, 1913, Sunday LONDON, Aug. 9. -- The explanation which is not forthcoming of the incident between Mme. Pavlova and Novikoff at the Palace Theatre has revived in one's memories the Pavlova-Mordkin quarrel. [ END OF FIRST PARAGRAPH ] See: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9506E3DC113BE6...
comment.authorname: maorlando God kept us 2012 leaning on Him 2013

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Pavlova Despite the fact that Novikoff said he would not dance with Pavlova again (in NYT article cited by maorlando), it would appear that he did come to the US the following year and dance with her. See NYT of April 7, 1914 "PAVLOWA IN NEW BALLET.; Excels in "Amarilla," with Mr. Novikoff, at the Manhattan." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9801E7DA163AE633A...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See michaelminn.net/andros/index.php?novikoff_laurent Laurent Novikoff (1888-1956) graduated from Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet School in 1906. He danced alternatively between Diaghilev (1909 and 1919-1921) and Pavlova's company (1911-1914 and 1921-1928). Novikoff was ballet master at the Chicago Opera from 1919-1933, and the Metropolitan Opera in New York from 1941-1945. See www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.pic-an11030051-5 for another picture of him. The National Library of Australia also has lots of pictures of Pavlova.
